newsitem.title: GERMANY: Thyssen considers E-Plus sell-off - Focus.
newsitem.headline: Thyssen considers E-Plus sell-off - Focus.

text.p: German industrial group Thyssen AG would decide in the next three months whether to sell its 30 percent share of the E-Plus mobile phone network, chief exeuctive said in a interview due to appear on Monday.

"We have the option to leave it purely mobile, develop an integrated telecommunications provider out of E-Plus or to sell our share," Dieter Vogel told the newsweekly Focus. "In any case, the decision should come in the next three months."
Thyssen, which recently agreed to form a joint steel company with rival Fried. Krupp AG Krupp-Hoesch, could ask more than three billion marks for its share, Vogel said.
Thyssen reportedly was interested in exchanging its E-Plus share for the Talkline mobile phone business of utility RWE AG. But Vogel told Focus he was sceptical of Talkline's business outlook.
E-Plus, in which BellSouth Corp of the U.S. and German utility Veba AG also own significant shares, trails well behind the mobile services of Mannesmann AG and Deutsche Telekom AG.
Thyssen has talked to BellSouth about expanding E-Plus into other fields of telecommunications.
